div.ab: MOORISH TERMS IN SPAIN. Por D. Eugenio Llaguno y Amirola y D. Juan Cean Bermudez.

list.item: Alhambra = dar alamra = casa real. Rey AlhamarLlaguno y Amírola (Noticias, vol. 1, pp. 246-7) is more tentative than it would appear here on etymology, with some saying the name comes from Rey [King] Alhamar, who ordered it built, and others that it is from 'dar-alamra', meaning 'casa real' [royal house].
Almaceria = maceriaLlaguno y Amírola has 'huerta cercada para siembra': fenced garden for planting. This is not far from the Italian 'maceria', a dry stone wall, which must be what WG is using.

Anaquel = shelves?WG is correct. Llaguno y Amírola has 'division en los armarios ó estantes para poner libros, platos ú otras cosas. Tambien significa el armario ó estante.' Division in cabinets or bookcases on which to put books, plates or other things. It also means the cabinet or bookcase.
Axaraca eastern ornamts. lazos.eastern ornaments. bows or loops.

Aximez [drawing: window] windowWG's drawing represents Llaguno y Amírola's greater detail: 'ventana de dos ó tres arcos con tres ó cinco columnitas, como las que hay en los edificios árabes y góticos.' Window with two or tree arches, with three or five little columns, like those found in Arab and Gothic buildings.
Azogue place of market at Segovia
AzulejosWG clearly does not need Llaguno y Amírola's lengthy definition of these tiles.
Borje torre metido en un CastilloLlaguno y Amírola has 'metida': tower placed within a Castle
Cenefa a border. Rambla = arenalsandy terrain
Maxaraque: solanaterrace or gallery facing the sun to East
Xarahiz = [drawing: circle] wallWG's drawing represents Llaguno y Amírola's greater detail: 'pared de piedra en obra circular.' Stone wall in circular form.
Zocodover zoco-dober plaza detrasLlaguno y Amírola has 'Zocodober': square behind as at Toledo behind AlcazarFortress
Aduana = casa de colecioncollections [i.e. customs] house

Aduar a [drawing: circle] r populationWG's drawing represents Llaguno y Amírola's greater detail: 'poblacion movible de los árabes. Casas, plural de dar, que significa casa, é indica que eran de forma orbicular, redondas dentro y fuera.' Movable town of the Arabs. Houses, plural of dar, which means house, and indicates that they were ring-shaped, round inside and outside.
Alamud cerrojo o pasador en ventanas palo principal del pabellon.bolt or latch on windows, main pole of a pavilion
Alarife. Sage mechanist. Gene el Arif = garden del maestro Jucef Nazar.of the master [architect] Jucef Nazar [i.e. the origin of the name of the Generalife, Granada]
AlbanarLlaguno y Amírola: 'Albañal' or 'Albañar' = conduits Almohadas. piedras de silleria resaltadas en los edificios.ashlar stones, sticking out of buildings
Alberga = estanque. DovetowerLlaguno y Amírola has 'Alberca': pond (estanque). 'Dovetower' is WG's translation of Llaguno y Amírola's definition of the next word in his list, 'Albergue'.

Albuhaire laguna also arches with azulejosLlaguno y Amírola: or 'Alboaire': lagoon. 'arches with azulejos' is WG's translation of Llaguno y Amírola's definition of the next word in his list, 'Albohaire'.
AlcolbaLlaguno y Amírola has 'Alcolea' little castle

Alfarge artesonado de los Techos. El pie de Piedra o ladrillo sobre que se coloca una cama &c y la misma cama coffered ceiling. The stone or brick base on which a bed etc is placed and the bed itself.Vide Queens bath AlhambraSee Queen's bath, Alhambra. This is WG's addition.

div.note: Selected from longer list in Eugenio Llaguno y Amírola, Noticias de los arquitectos y arquitectura de España..., 4 vols (Madrid: Imprenta Real, 1829), vol. 1, pp. 243-51. Some of WG's definitions are in Llaguno y Amírola's Spanish, others are translated into English or Italian and many are WG's own summaries of Llaguno y Amírola's longer definitions.
